channel.title: Improper Fractions
channel.description:
I've been study for an exam and I need help with these 2 questions.
Question 1:
The Expression of [b][i]5x/6[/i] + [i]4x/7[/i][/b] simplify's to:
A. 16/27. B. 24x[sup]2[/sup]/18 C. 4/3 D. 4x[sup]2[/sup]/3
Question 2
The Expression of [b][i]8x/9[/i] / [i]3x/2[/i][/b] simplify's to:
A. 16/27. B. 24x[sup]2[/sup]/18 C. 4/3 D. 4x[sup]2[/sup]/3
I don't just want the answers, I want to know how to get the answer and how to do Improper Fractions.
Thanks, also does anyone know any good websites I can learn all about fractions, thanks.

item.title: Improper Fractions
item.dc:creator: @matzie matzie
item.description:
@matzie wrote:

Simple.
Addition and subtraction- common denominator
ALWAYS deal with what is in parentheses first
Simplest way is:
5x/6 + 4x/7
7 * 6 = 42

=(75)x/42 + (46)x/42
=35x/42+24x/42
=(35x+24x)/42

Multiplication:
straight through.
5x/17 * 4x/33
=(5x4x)/(1733)

Division:
multiply by the reciprocal(right word?)
Meaning, flip one or the others numerator with the denominator

(8x/9) / (3x/2)
= (8x/9) * (2/3x)
can now treat it the same as multiplication.
= (8x2)/(93x)
= (16x)/(27x) x’s cancel
= (16/27)

This is so much easier on paper lol!

Read full topic

item.title: Improper Fractions
item.dc:creator: @tigerclan tigerclan
item.description:
@tigerclan wrote:

[quote=“sppt, post:2, topic:519303”][quote author=Skyro link=topic=637767.msg4298538#msg4298538 date=1368617189]

Thanks, also does anyone know any good websites I can learn all about fractions, thanks.

[/quote]
Khan Academy, use the search bar thing to find whatever you’re looking for.

As for those questions, it seems like the right answer isn’t there.
The first question can be solved by multiplying both fractions so that they’ve got the same denominator, and then it’s just the matter of adding them together.[/quote]

Yes, please use khan academy, it’s amazing.

Read full topic

item.title: Improper Fractions
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Yea, it looks like the right answer for the first one isn’t there…

As for the second one, remember dividing by a fraction is the same as multiplying by the reciprocal, and multiplying fractions is easy peasy.

8x/9 / 3x/2
is the same as
8x/9 * 2/3x

And that’s just 16x/27x, where the x cancels out giving you 16/27

Read full topic

item.title: Improper Fractions
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

Skyro:

Thanks, also does anyone know any good websites I can learn all about fractions, thanks.

Khan Academy, use the search bar thing to find whatever you’re looking for.

As for those questions, it seems like the right answer isn’t there.
The first question can be solved by multiplying both fractions so that they’ve got the same denominator, and then it’s just the matter of adding them together.

Read full topic
